Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Explore the Theoretical Framework of Engineering Knowledge Transfer in Cybermanufacturing Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
3D Printing, also known as additive manufacturing, offers the potential for individuals and companies to design and produce customized parts in quantities as small as a single unit. However, unlike conventional mass production, for which production machines are adjusted to maintain quality by periodically measuring the parts that are produced, the small lots produced in 3D Printing do not provide the opportunity to tune the production machines in the same way. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will investigate a statistical method for adjusting the production quality of a 3D Printing machine based on experience in producing parts of different part types. Such a tool has the capability to be offered to manufacturers as a cloud-based utility, with possible extension to aggregating data from similar machines at different sites.

The fundamental barrier to knowledge transfer between engineering processes lies in lurking variables, which are process variables that are unobserved due to infeasibility of measurement or insufficient knowledge. The project will model and mitigate the effects of lurking variables in terms of observable control variables to enable a novel gray-box model transfer strategy for additive manufacturing systems. The proposed research tasks include: (1) establishing a theoretical formulation of effect equivalence to quantify effects of lurking variables, (2) exploring a statistical foundation for learning effect equivalence, (3) verifying effect equivalence models and their robustness, and (4) obtaining engineering insight from effect equivalence and developing a multi-resolution measurement strategy. The project is expected to produce a mathematical formulation of engineering effect equivalence, demonstrate the formulation in predicting geometric shape deformation of 3D products built by additive manufacturing machines, and a multi-resolution measurement strategy for equivalence-based additive manufacturing process control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project at Florida State University conducted validation of engineering effect equivalence theories for generalizing quality control strategies from the 3D printing of basic shapes to complex shapes. In addition, the data learning algorithm to enable knowledge transfer among multiple machines or devices are extended to other applications including performance modeling and monitoring in machining processes, electric power systems, and solar panels. 

The outcomes of this project at FSU can be summarized as follows, 

1. Quality inspection based on a vision system was built to monitor inline printing errors in support of data collection for this project. 

2. The project established a cloud platform to share/exchange the quality data along with printing parameters among multiple 3D printers. The cloud platform creates an inter-connected 3D printing system with improved quality control.

3. Joint quality prediction methods were developed for the inter-connected 3D printers, by which the printing errors for one 3D printer can be jointly learned with another 3D printer based on the similar extrusion deposition mechanism. The prediction errors have been demonstrated to outperform the error prediction for each 3D printer. 

4. The joint learning methods from this project were generalized for surface machining processes and performance modeling and monitoring for electric power systems and solar panels. Transfer learning algorithms were developed to forecast electric power output over time by integrating the data shared from multiple consumer communities. 

5. This project partially contributed to three journal paper publications and one journal paper submission. In addition, one conference paper was submitted. 

6. The results were presented at (1) an additive manufacturing workshop (FACAM- Foundations of Accuracy Control for Additive Manufacturing) at the University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, and (2) 2018 INFORMS (Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences) Annual Conference at Pheonix, AZ.

7. Two Ph.D. students are partially supported by this project in 2018. 

8. The project contributed to the development of project topics for two REU projects for an NSF HBCU-RISE educational program in Summer 2018. Two minority undergraduate students including an African American were involved in this experience.

9. The outcome of this project contributed to the development of a regular size NSF project on this research and new research projects on the Internet-of-Things (IoT) additive manufacturing quality control by integrating the production and quality data shared on a cloud platform (cloud data). The results generated from this project lead to a new research direction in cloud data fusion with IoT applications to improve data modeling and monitoring accuracy.   

 

 


Last Modified: 11/25/2018
Modified by: Hui Wang

In addition, the data learning algorithm to enable knowledge transfer among multiple machines or devices are extended to other applications including performance modeling and monitoring in machining processes, electric power systems, and solar panels. The outcomes of this project at FSU can be summarized as follows, 1. Quality inspection based on a vision system was built to monitor inline printing errors in support of data collection for this project. 2. The cloud platform creates an inter-connected 3D printing system with improved quality control. 3. Joint quality prediction methods were developed for the inter-connected 3D printers, by which the printing errors for one 3D printer can be jointly learned with another 3D printer based on the similar extrusion deposition mechanism. The prediction errors have been demonstrated to outperform the error prediction for each 3D printer. 4. The joint learning methods from this project were generalized for surface machining processes and performance modeling and monitoring for electric power systems and solar panels. Transfer learning algorithms were developed to forecast electric power output over time by integrating the data shared from multiple consumer communities. 5. This project partially contributed to three journal paper publications and one journal paper submission. In addition, one conference paper was submitted. 6. Two minority undergraduate students including an African American were involved in this experience. 9. The outcome of this project contributed to the development of a regular size NSF project on this research and new research projects on the Internet-of-Things (IoT) additive manufacturing quality control by integrating the production and quality data shared on a cloud platform (cloud data). The results generated from this project lead to a new research direction in cloud data fusion with IoT applications to improve data modeling and monitoring accuracy.
